content.webTitle: Letters: In search of a fair deal on social housing

fields.headline: In search of a fair deal on social housing
fields.bodyText: I trust Simon Hughes much more than Grant Shapps on social housing issues, but neither "right to buy" nor "swelling numbers on the waiting list" is where to focus (Coalition risks Tory alarm as Thatcher's right-to-buy policy faces review, 17 September). "Right to buy" sales are now minimal, with the bigger, more desirable flats gone; and waiting list figures should be no basis for policymaking, as almost anyone can nominate themselves, often in as many council areas as they like – and why wouldn't you, if you're young and canny and sniff the possible prize of lifetime tenure on a downtown flat for just £80 a week? Low-cost housing must be there for those who need it – but with several hundred billion pounds tied up in social housing nationally, it is right to ask if we are using these resources well. If we have to put up a "no vacancies" sign because that housing is largely tied up in lifetime tenure – regardless of changes in family need, or household income – then we may be disproportionately benefiting our long-term sitting tenants at the expense of those in real need. The price they pay is scarring years, or decades, in cramped hostels or B&Bs, or insecure private-rent. If we accept that low-cost housing is a right for life, once in, then the way to help those newly in need is to build much more social housing, and we should. But this doesn't answer the long-term question: what do we do when that fills up too? This coalition government is exactly the right place to debate such issues. Cllr Chris Naylor Lib Dem cabinet member for homes and housing strategy, Camden 2006-10 • House prices are falling (Report, 14 September) amid uncertainty over the effect of public spending reductions and fears of a double-dip recession. Is it not therefore time to ask what will be the likely effect on a fragile housing market of the severe curbs on housing benefit proposed by the chancellor? Robin Johnson Nottingham
